page.name: Background Readings
page.intro: Read these articles when you start this course. These articles will provide background knowledge and a common vocabulary about SCL.
page.content:
General

The first reading is from the NRC Report: Improving Adult Literacy Instruction: Options for Practice and Research.  Read pages 14 to 26, Motivating Adult Learners to Persist, which describes the best available research on learning and motivation and offers principles and practices for developing instruction for adults. Drawing from the full report is a booklet, Supporting Learning and Motivation, which synthesizes the research and presents recommendations for practice in a user-friendly manner. You can download this booklet at the National Academies Press website.

Helping Adults Persist: Four Supports by John Comings, Andrea Parrella, & Lisa Soricone

The second reading is a TEAL Center Fact No. 6 Sheet on Student Centered Learning. It makes explicit how SCL applies to the adult education context. Bookmark this Fact Sheet for future reference and share with colleagues.

Math

The Effects of Continuing Goal-setting on Persistence in a Math Classroom
Instructor Pam Meader describes a practitioner inquiry project she conducted with her adult math students to identify ways to reduce program-wide attrition.  Her data collection and analysis revealed obstacles and supports that influence student persistence in math classes, and which differ from those identified in studies of general adult basic education programming.

Changing the Way We Teach Math
In these two chapters from her manual Changing the Way We Teach Math, instructor Kate Nonesuch discusses resistance and emotions felt by both students and teachers, and how these affect student persistence in the math classroom. Changing the Way We Teach Math: A Manual for Teaching Basic Math to Adults, pp.9-23
